awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Zeolite catalysts for biomass upgrading
awd_abstract_narration:
Manufacturing of plastics and other industrial chemicals depends on key chemical building blocks sourced primarily from petroleum and natural gas feedstocks. Increasingly, renewable resources such as biomass are used to make the same product or drop-in substitutes. This biomass is typically made up of crop residues or purposely grown plants that are not competitors for food agriculture. Current biobased chemicals such as hydoxymethylfurfural, furfural, and their derivatives are promising drop-in replacements for chemicals made from fossil fuels and have been identified as top platform chemicals from biorefining processes. This research project studies the manufacture of these biomass-derived platform chemicals using catalysts that can promote higher product yields and a lower environmental footprint. Parallel objectives of this project are to integrate the research activities with education and outreach programs to provide significant educational opportunities at the undergraduate and graduate education levels and to the general public. The educational outreach includes a joint course between Montana State University and the Colorado School of Mines designed as website modules and Skype-based lectures. The results of this project are being disseminated to the scientific community and implemented in course material lectures to benefit the student body at both institutions. 

The central theme of this collaborative project is to demonstrate that rationally designing nanocrystalline zeolites with tailored properties can lead to effective catalysts exhibiting high catalytic activity for biomass and sugar conversion into commercially useful platform chemicals. The specific objectives of this work are to: (1) develop chemical synthesis strategies to rationally design nanocrystalline zeolite catalysts, (2) understand the basic formation mechanisms governing the transformation of precursor solutions into zeolites, (3) evaluate catalytic performance of nanocrystalline zeolite catalysts for the catalytic conversion of sugars and biomass into furfural and derivatives, and (4) elucidate fundamental structure/catalytic relationships of microporous nanocrystalline catalysts in the conversion of sugars into hydoxymethylfurfural, furfural, and their derivatives. This fundamental research ties understanding of synthesis conditions to properties of the zeolite, including crystal size distribution, pore size, surface area and acid site distribution, to catalytic activity and to product yield of targeted dehydration products. The research also aims to establish novel self-assembly concepts as general synthesis methods for a broad range of zeolite catalysts that will have tunable properties and convert biomass into industrial relevant chemicals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to establish appropriate synthesis conditions for the rational design of zeolite nanocrystalline catalysts that demonstrate high catalytic activity for the conversion of sugars into valuable platform chemicals. Mineral acids have been widely used for the conversion of sugars into these platform chemicals, but require concentrated acid to be stored and need to be neutralized prior to further processing. A more effective approach that eliminates the use of mineral acids is to identify solid acid catalysts that can be easily recovered after reaction, and reused. In this respect, zeolites, a subclass of porous crystalline aluminosilicate or silica polymorphs, combine highly desirable catalytic properties such as uniform micropores, high surface areas, and exceptional thermal and chemical stability that make them ideal candidates for this reaction. Specifically, our research efforts focused on using the rationally designed catalyst for the conversion of xylose, fructose, and glucose into furfural and HMF

The catalytic performance of multiple zeolites, grown on zeolite 5A beads, were evaluated for the production of furfural from xylose and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and levulinic acid from glucose in aqueous systems and it was found that the SAPO-34 beads showed promise for the dehydration reactions. During this research, it was discovered that the solvent plays an important role in the reaction and that solvent polarity and reaction conditions (time and temperature) can be used to estimate xylose conversion and furfural yields.

We developed multiple models that predict the xylose conversion and furfural yield using reaction time, temperature, and the polarity of the solvent. A linear model was developed over the linear range of data and showed that both xylose conversion and furfural yield can be predicted simultaneously. More recently, a non-linear Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model that used the entire data range can predict xylose conversions and furfural yields with greater than 90% accuracy. Additionally, a Gaussian Process Regression model was built for comparison and a manuscript is currently in progress. The developed models have the potential to significantly reduce the amount of time spent on determining the best solvent system for xylose to furfural dehydration. Additionally, resources will be saved as solvents that have low polarity and low reaction time and temperatures can be eliminated from experimental plans. Applying this research to and developing models for other reactions could save valuable resources by eliminating the method of "guess and check."

Additionally, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) work was completed to elucidate the location of sugar and water molecules in the zeolite catalyst structure. Transport of xylose into the small pore zeolite SAPO-34 was studied and it was found that unique relaxation patterns were achieved. The NMR results were more complicated than expected as the phenomena seen with the xylose and zeolites was unique and not commonly seen. These relaxation patterns may be common to other micorporous materials, which could lead to a better understanding of molecular transport in catalysts, among other materials. This work was published with our collaborator, Dr. Joe Seymour.

During the entire project duration, this grant as provided opportunities for research and mentoring for three Master?s students and 15 undergraduate students, which included almost 50 semesters of research. Of the 18 students supported, one Master?s student is Hispanic, nine students identify as female, and two students were veterans. Six peer-reviewed publications were published that were funded through this grant with two additional publications anticipated. 

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2021
Modified by: Stephanie G Wettstein
